text: Toyota is one of the largest
and best automotive providers.
Our culture goes back many, many years,
but we have over 1,800 dealerships,
over 63,000 employees in North America,
and have 12 main manufacturing plants,

with the 13th being the
battery plant coming right up.

It's disparate in terms of,
you know, you have data lakes,

we have other platforms
that the data may sit in.

We have databases, we have
third party data stores.

So how do you create
that interconnectedness
and that cohesion so that you do not have

to spend time just bringing all
of your data into one place,

but you can actually grab
the data from multiple places
and then get to that insight
and get to those models very quickly.

Amazon SageMaker Unified
Studio has the promise
and the ability to do that.
I think this is such an opportunity
where we can leverage the catalog,
we can leverage the MLOps pipelines,
and we can leverage all that suite

and the capabilities to
launch models rather quickly.

And be able to share
models right across the
data science community.
Amazon SageMaker Lakehouse has a lot
of promise in terms of making sure

that we can pull together
data from multiple data stores
to be able to now pull data from all
of these disparate sources

and create a unified way in
which we can access this data
and then deliver value.
Our goal as an organization,

and if we want to be competitive
right, in the future, we have

to make sure that we change
the way in which we're
serving up data.

It's extremely exciting
to see all the development

that AWS is doing in
many different areas so

that we can leverage
these capabilities in a
much quicker manner.

And then again, our focus
is really on providing value
to the customer so

that we are not fighting
about where's the data,
who owns the data, is it safe and secure?

But rather we're spending
the time on insight creation.
